questions.text: Best diagnostic test for unilateral stress fracture is _______
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic test for a unilateral stress fracture is MRI.

For stress fracture, Best diagnostic test for,

  • Unilateral stress fracture– MRI
  • Bilateral stress fracture- Bone scan

If unilateral or bilateral is not mentioned then MRI is the preferred choice.

questions.text: For tuberculosis of the spine the radiological investigation of choice is
questions.solution:
The radiological investigation of choice for TB spine is MRI.

MRI can also be reliably used to differentiate between tuberculous and pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.

Patients with tuberculous vertebral osteomyelitis have a significantly higher incidence of a well-defined paraspinal abnormal signal, thin and smooth walled abscess cavities, particularly at paraspinal or intraosseous locations, sub-ligamentous spread to three or more vertebral levels and involvement of multiple vertebral bodies.

questions.text: The following statements are true about the given image except

choices.text: Pain on attempt of hyperextension of fingers

questions.solution:
The above image classically shows Infectious Tenosynovitis.

Tenosynovitis

  • Infection of the flexor tendon sheath.
  • Puncture wounds on flexor creases
  • May involve ulnar and radial bursa
  • Kanavel’s sign
    • 4 cardinal signs are
    • Tenderness over involved sheath
    • Finger in flexion deformity
    • Pain on attempt of hyperextension of fingers
    • Swelling of involved part
  • Note:

    Extensor and flexor tendon sheaths have two surfaces: an inner visceral layer (visceral paratenon) adherent to the tendon and an outer parietal layer (parietal paratenon) abutting adjacent structures such as adjacent muscles and retinacular structures. Normally, the visceral and parietal layers abut one another. In the setting of tenosynovitis, the potential space between these two layers may fill with inflammatory or purulent fluid.

    The visceral and parietal layers of most tendons coalesce at the proximal and distal ends to produce a closed tendon sheath compartment. The thumb flexor sheath is contiguous with the radial bursa, and the small finger flexor sheath is contiguous with the ulnar bursa; these two bursae extend proximally into the carpal tunnel. The radial and ulnar bursae communicate at the wrist in 50 to 80 percent of patients . Therefore, infection in the thumb tendon sheath can spread to the small finger sheath via the ulnar bursa (or vice versa), creating a "horseshoe abscess."

questions.text: A man after having a binge of alcohol on Saturday night complains of wrist drop the following morning. What type of injury is suspected ?
questions.solution:
Neuropraxia is seen typically in

  • Pressure paralysis in states of drunkenness (‘Saturday night palsy’)
  • Crutch palsy
  • Milder types of tourniquet palsy
  • It is due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.
  • It is a reversible physiological nerve conduction block in which there is loss of some types of sensation and muscle power followed by spontaneous recovery after a few days or weeks.

questions.text: Wartenberg sign in ulnar nerve injury indicates the paralysis of which of the following muscles
questions.solution:
Wartenberg sign refers to the abducted position of little finger. It is due to weakness of palmar interossei.

  • Dorsal interossei – Loss of abduction of finger against resistance – Igawa test.
  • Adductor pollicis – Froment’s sign

questions.text: A 40-year-old hypothyroid female complains of heaviness and tingling in the left index and middle finger, the pain often increases in the night and is relieved on moving the hand for a while. Which of the following is not a clinical test for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the female is suffering from carpal tunnel syndrome.

Finkelstein test is done for de Quervain’s synovitis.

  • Hold the patient’s hand with his thumb tucked firmly unto the palm.
  • Then turn the wrist into full ulnar deviation.
  • In a positive test, this will elicit sharp pain in the  effected sheath.

Phalen’s test, Tinel’s sign, Tourniquet’s test are done for Carpal tunnel syndrome.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: The primary pathology in athletic pubalgia is
questions.solution:
Athletic pubalgia refers to chronic pain on the inguinal or pubic region on exertion.

The primary pathology is in the insertion of rectus abdominis muscle on the pubis.

  • Its also called as Sportsman’s hernia or Gilmore’s groin.
  • Management is conservative.
  • Nesovic’s operation is reserved for resistant cases.

questions.text: Commonest ligament injured in ankle injury is
questions.solution:
• Lateral ligament complex especially the anterior talofibular ligament is most commonly involved on ankle injuries.
  • The second most common ligament to be injured is Calcaneofibular ligament.

questions.text: Among the marked structures all are components of O’Donoghue triad except
questions.solution:
The marked structure B represents ‘Posterior cruciate ligament’.

It is not a part of O’Donoghue triad.

O’Donoghue triad involves:

  • Medial collateral ligament
  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty with pain and swelling of the forearm. Her mother gives a history of a fall while running in the playground. Radiograph image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a fracture in the proximal third of the ulna and there is a dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint, which points to a diagnosis of Monteggia fracture-dislocation. 

Dislocation of the head of the radius can be detected using McLaughlin’s line (radiocapitellar line). A line drawn along the center of the shaft of the radius will cut the capitellum of the humerus in the center irrespective of the position of the elbow. In Monteggia fracture this relationship is disturbed. 

The mechanism of injury in these fractures is usually a fall on the outstretched hand. Clinical features include:

  • Deformity in the proximal forearm - due to ulnar fracture. The dislocation of the head of the radius may be masked by the swelling
  • Pain and tenderness on the lateral side of the elbow - due to proximal radioulnar dislocation

Monteggia fracture is treated surgically (fracture of necessity). The ulnar fracture is reduced and bone restored to full length. It is then fixed with a plate and screws. The radial head usually reduces once the ulna is fixed.

The below image shows radiocapitellar line (McLaughlin’s line) in a normal x-ray. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Fracture shown in the radiograph is:
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows Aviator’s fracture. 

An aviator fracture is a coronal-plane fracture of the neck of the talus resulting from forced dorsiflexion of ankle. 

It is the second most common talar fracture, after talar dome fractures. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

questions.text: The given X ray of left knee joint suggests
questions.solution:
The given X ray of left knee joint shows immature skeleton with expansile multi-cystic lytic lesions in the metaphysis of tibia. It is the classical presentation of a aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC). 

Aneurysmal bone cysts (ABCs) are benign, expansile lesions of bone composed of blood-filled cystic spaces. They predominantly affect children and teenagers with an equal sex distribution. ABCs are most commonly seen in the metaphyses of long bones, particularly the femur, tibia and humerus. In the spine , they usually affect the posterior elements. Patients typically present with pain and swelling. When affecting the spine, presentation can be with nerve root impingement and neurological impairment. 

ABCs appear as a subperiosteal, poorly defined osteolytic lesion, and progressively elevating and eroding the cortex. MRI shows typically cysts with multiple intralesional septations and fluid levels. Histologically, ABCs are composed of blood-filled, cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae which may comprise woven bone in chronic lesions. An ABC can appear as a solid lesion, which resembles a giant-cell lesion but in immature skeleton.

ABC-like areas can be seen in other benign tumours and occasionally malignant lesions where there has been haemorrhage within the tumour (secondary ABC). Curettage of the lesion at the time of biopsy ,debriding the cystic cavity wall, is often effective though recurrence can occur in up to 20% of cases. Radiation is effective in stimulating cyst calcification but risk of secondary tumors due to radiation and growth arrest due to epiphyseal damage in present.

Other options -

Option A - Simple bone cyst(SBC) also presents in the first 2 decades of life in the immature bone most commonly in the metaphysis of humerus followed by proximal femur and proximal tibia. They are solitary, usually unilocular cystic bone cavity lined by a fibrous membrane and filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid. Males are more frequently affected. In majority of the cases, they are incidental findings as they are asymptomatic, occasionally they present as pathological fractures.

X-rays show well-defined ,centrally placed lytic lesions in the metaphyseal areas expanding and thinning the cortices. It often abuts the physis but usually is not aggressive like ABCs (does not cross the physis). When fractures occur, a small fragment may be seen within the cavity, the classic ‘fallen leaf’ sign. MRI shows homogeneous fluid-filled cavity. 

Option C - Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. Primary osteosarcomas present most commonly during adolescence whereas secondary osteosarcomas present during the 7th decade of life. They arise from the metaphysis of long bones, especially the distal femur or the proximal tibia (i.e. around the knee joint).

Clinically, they present with worsening pain and swelling. The pain is described as non-mechanical and is often worse during the night. X-rays features include Codman’s triangle due to periosteal elevation from new bone formation and ‘Sunburst’ appearance due to rapid growth when the periosteum cannot lay down a new layer.

Option D -Giant cell tumors(GCT) or osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 (mature skeleton) years with slight female predominance. It affects the ends of long bones, involving metaphysis/epiphysis of long bones. GCT is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

X-ray features include the classical soap-bubble appearance , eccentric location and expansile in nature elevating the cortex.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with painful swelling over the left shoulder. Radiograph of the shoulder showed an osteolytic area with stippled calcification over the proximal humeral epiphysis. Biopsy of the lesion revealed an immature fibrous matrix with scattered giant cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological report suggests the diagnosis of chondroblastoma.

Chondroblastoma / Codman’s tumor

  • Well circumscribed lesion
  • Epiphysis of long bone
  • Chicken wire appearance due to calcification
  • Histopathology
    • Chondroid tissue composed of round cells (‘chondroblasts’)
    • Scattered multinucleated giant cells

questions.text: The term floating knee refers to

choices.text: Damage to both ACL and PCL
Tear of both Medial collateral ligament and lateral collateral ligament
Femoral shaft fracture with proximal tibial metaphyseal fracture

questions.solution: The combination of femoral shaft and tibial shaft fractures on the same side, produces a ‘floating knee’.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a bone curette.

Option A. Periosteal elevator

Option C. Bone hook

Option D. Osteotome

questions.text: K.L. Splint is used for
questions.solution:
K.L. splint is one of the treatment modalities of Plantar fasciitis.

Plantar fasciitis

Painful inflammatory process of plantar fascia.

Incidental finding – Heel spur, bony calcification of the calcaneus heel bone.

questions.text: The given image depicts
questions.solution:
The above image shows a Thompson’s prosthesis

Option A. Austin Moore prosthesis

Option C. Bipolar prosthesis

questions.text: The term vertebroplasty refers to

choices.text: Replacement of vertebral body along with Intervertebral disc

questions.solution:
• Vertebroplasty is a treatment modality of Vertebral compression fractures.
  • It refers to the transpedicular injection of methacrylate or bone graft substitute paste in order to stop further deformity and control pain.

questions.text: Corduroy or Jailhouse appearance is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
• Corduroy or Jailhouse appearance is the radiographic finding in Hemangioma of a Spine.
  • On CT scan – Polka dot pattern is seen on cross section.
  • It is due to the thickened vertically aligned trabeculae.

questions.text: Bankart lesion is usually seen at
questions.solution:
Bankart lesion refers to detachment of labrum and capsule from anterior rim of glenoid.

It is seen in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of shoulder joint.

 

The following X-ray shows Bankart lesion:

Hill sachs lesion(X-ray below) refers to a defect in posterolateral part of humeral head.

questions.text: In CTEV Inversion of the foot occurs at:-
questions.solution:
Inversion and eversion occurs at Talocalcaneal or subtalar joint.

In case of CTEV

The four main components of clubfoot are:

  1. hindfoot varus (calcaneus is too far medial)
  2. equinus heel (fixed plantar flexion of the heel)
  3. metatarsus adductus (adduction of the metatarsals with forefoot varus)
  4. talonavicular subluxation

questions.text: Transient synovitis of the hip is characterized by all except:

choices.text: The attitude of hip is adduction and internal rotation
USG of the hip reveals widening of the joint space

questions.solution:
Attitude of hip in a case of transient synovitis of hip joint is flexion, abduction and external rotation.

Transient synovitis is also known as irritable hip or observation hip or coxitis serosa or coxalgia fugax.

  • It is non-specific, short-lived synovitis.
  • Characteristically, symptoms last for 1–2 weeks and then subside spontaneously; hence the synonym ‘transient synovitis’.

Etiology

  • Etiology
  • Trauma
  • Allergy

Clinical feature:

  • Age group affected - 3–8-year olds.
  • Boys are affected twice as often as girls
  • Painful limp - often intermittent and following activity
  • It is the most common cause of an acute limp or hip pain in children
  • Cardinal sign is restriction of all movements with pain at the extremes of the range in all directions.

Investigations:

  • WBC count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein concentration are usually within normal limits.
  • X-rays - subtle widening of the medial joint space (1–2 mm)

Treatment:

  • Bed rest
  • Reduced activity
  • Observation

questions.text: 55 years old male patient having arthritic changes at small joints of hands (PIP, DIP & CMC joint of the thumb). No changes at wrist and MCP joints. What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Osteoarthritis characteristically involves
    • Distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node)
    • Proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node)
    • 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb)
  • Osteoarthritis doesn’t affect metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.
  • Hence most probable diagnosis is osteoarthritis.

questions.text: All the osteochondritis are correctly matched except
questions.solution:
Osgood Schlatter is osteochondritis of tibial tuberosity.

Osteochondritis of lower pole of patella is known as Johanson-Larsens.

Bone affected Name

questions.text: Cock up splint is used in:
questions.solution:
Cock up splint is used in the treatment of radial nerve injury.

Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost in radial nerve injury (wrist, thumb and finger drop).

questions.text: Maffucci syndrome is associated with
questions.solution:
Maffucci’s disease is characterized by the development of

  • Multiple enchondromas
  • Soft-tissue haemangiomas of the skin and viscera

Both bony and soft tissue lesions are more prone for malignant transformation.

questions.text: Avulsion of Extensor tendon give rise to
questions.solution:
Mallet finger also known as baseball finger refers to avulsion of extensor tendon of distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx.

Mechanism of injury:

Forcibly flexing the finger while it is in extension (usual cause) or direct trauma.

Attitude:

  • Terminal joint is held flexed and the patient cannot straighten it.
  • Passive movement is normal.
  • The PIP joint may become hyperextended (‘swan-neck’).

Treatment:

  • No bone injury - a plastic splint with the DIP joint in extension for 8 weeks, followed by 4 weeks of night splintage.
  • Large fragment (>50 per cent) and subluxation of the DIP joint – surgery.

Option a: In swan neck deformity, PIP is hyperextended and DIP is flexed.

Option b: Trigger finger is stenosing tenosynovitis of flexor tendon of affected finger.

Option d: Boutonniere deformity involves flexion deformity of the PIP joint and extension of the DIP joint.

questions.text: All are correct match for entrapment neuropathies except

choices.text: Meralgia paresthetica: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.solution:
Tarsal tunnel syndrome refers to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus.

Entrapment syndrome Nerve involved
Carpal tunnel syndrome Median nerve
Pronator syndrome Median nerve
Cubital tunnel syndrome Ulnar nerve
Guyon’s canal syndrome Ulnar nerve
Thoracic outlet syndrome Lower trunk of brachial plexus
Piriformis syndrome Sciatic nerve
Cheralgia paresthetica Superficial radial nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Tarsal tunnel syndrome Posterior tibial nerve
Morton’s metatarsalgia Interdigital nerve compression

questions.text: Aeroplane splint is used in the management of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Aeroplane splint is used in the management of Erb’s palsy. 

C5 - C6 injury is seen in Erb's palsy. It is typically seen in overweight babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery. There is paralysis of the abductors, external rotators of the shoulder, and the supinators. The arm will be held to the side in internal rotation and pronation with loss of finger extension.

Other options

Option A: Median nerve palsy, at the level of the forearm and wrist, leads to an inability to abduct the thumb and loss of sensation over the lateral three and a half digits. When the injury to the median nerve is higher up, like in the arm, along with the symptoms mentioned above, there is paralysis of the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles. The hand is usually held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight, which is called the pointing index sign. Wearing a wrist splint at night can help maintain the wrist in a neutral position, reducing pressure on the median nerve and providing relief from nocturnal symptoms.

Option C: Cock-up splint is used in the management of radial nerve palsy.

Option D: Knuckle bender splint is used in cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated to correct and prevent MCP(metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

questions.text: Which of the following is an avulsion fracture
questions.solution:
Clay-Shoveller’s fracture refers to avulsion fracture of spinous process of 7th cervical vertebra.

  • Option a: Jefferson fracture is burst fracture of ring of Atlas (C1 vertebra).
  • Option b: Hangman’s fracture - bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis of C2 and the C2/3 disc is torn.
  • Option c: Undertaker’s fracture refers to tearing of C6-7 disc space causing subluxation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the vertebra

Burst fracture - Vertical compression injury

Chance fracture - horizontal fracture of the vertebral body

Clay-shoveller's fracture - spinous process fracture of C6, C7 or T1

Dens fracture - Odontoid process fracture

Hangman's fracture - fracture of both pedicles of C2

Holdsworth fracture - unstable spinal fracture-dislocation at the thoracolumbar junction

Jefferson's fracture - fracture of first cervical vertebra

Motorcyclist's fracture - transverse fracture across base of the skull

Whiplash's injury - hyperextension followed by flexion 

Undertaker's fracture -Post-mortem fracture of the lower cervical spine with C6-C7 disc disruption

questions.text: Denis classification to assess spine stability divides spinal cord into how many parts
questions.solution:
Denis 3 column classification to assess spinal stability includes:

  • The posterior osseoligamentous complex (or posterior column) consisting of
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament
  • The middle column comprising the
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • The anterior column composed of
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament

questions.text: Tarsometatarsal amputation is known as
questions.solution:
Lisfranc amputation is partial foot amputation through tarsometatarsal joint.

  • option a: Pirgoff is a type of below ankle amputation.(removal of forefoot and talus followed by calcaneotibial arthrodesis)
  • Option d: Symes is a type of above ankle amputations.(amputation performed at level of talocrural joint and plantar pad of fat is dissected from the calcaneum and preserved)
  • Option c: Chopart’s amputation is partial foot amputation through mid-tarsal joint.

questions.text: Paget’s disease is associated with
questions.solution:
Paget’s disease can result in malignant transformation mainly osteosarcoma.

Incidence of malignant transformation is around 1%.

questions.text: Denosumab a monoclonal antibody against RANKL receptor is used in the treatment of
questions.solution:
• Denosumab is used in the treatment of osteoporosis.
  • RANK-RANKL interaction is necessary for osteoclastogenesis.
  • This drug interrupts the RANKL–RANK interaction and thus reduces osteoclastic activity and bone resorption.

Uses of Denosumab:

  1. Osteoporosis
  2. Aromatase Inhibitor Induced Bone Loss
  3. Androgen Deprivation Induced Bone Loss
  4. Glucocorticoid-Induced Osteoporosis
  5. Multiple myelomas and  bone metastases from solid tumors
  6. Giant Cell Tumor
  7. Hypercalcemia of Malignancy

questions.text: Candle bones are seen in
questions.solution:
Candle bones (melorheostosis, Leri’s disease)

  • Non-familial condition
  • C/F: Pain and stiffness in one limb
  • X-rays show irregular patches of sclerosis, usually distributed in a linear fashion through the limb- appearance is reminiscent of wax that congeals on the side of a burning candle.
  • Associated with scleroderma and joint contractures.

Spotted bones (osteopoikilosis)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • X-rays - numerous white spots distributed throughout the skeleton
  • Whitish spots in the skin (disseminated lenticular dermatofibrosis)

Striped bones (osteopathia striata)

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Asymptomatic
  • X-rays show lines of increased density parallel to the shafts of long bones, but radiating like a fan in the pelvis.

questions.text: Looser zone is a feature of
questions.solution:
The classical lesion of osteomalacia is the Looser zone, a thin transverse band of rarefaction in an otherwise normal-looking bone.

Other radiological features of osteomalacia are

  • Biconcave vertebrae (from disc pressure)
  • Lateral indentation of the acetabula (‘trefoil’ pelvis’)
  • Spontaneous fractures of the ribs, pubic rami, femoral neck or the metaphyses above and below the knee.

questions.text: Caffey’s disease is
questions.solution:
Caffey’s disease is also known as infantile cortical hyperostosis.

It is self limiting disorder

  • Most common age group affected is <6 months old.
  • Spontaneous resolution by 3 years of age. 
  • Most common bone affected in sporadic case – mandible.
  • Most common bone affected in familial case – tibia> ulna.
  • Symptoms:
    • Painful swelling over the tubular bones and/or the mandible.
    • The child may be feverish and irritable, refusing to move the affected limb.
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays - Periosteal new-bone formation resulting in thickening of the cortex of affected bone.
  • Treatment – antibiotics are sometimes employed.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in Klippel-Feil syndrome except
questions.solution:
Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital fusion of the cervical vertebrae that may involve two segments, a congenital block
vertebra, or the entire cervical spine.

Congenital cervical fusion is a result of failure of normal segmentation of the cervical somites during the third to eighth week of life.

The classic features of Klippel-Feil syndrome are a short neck, low posterior hairline, and limited range of neck motion.

Associated anamolies are

  • Scoliosis in 60% patients
  • Renal abnormalities (30%)
  • VSD (4-14%)
  • Deafness (30%)
  • Synkinesis (20%)
  • Respiratory anomalies like failure of lobe formation, ectopic lungs and restriction of lung function
  • Sprengel deformity in 20%

questions.text: Marker of bone resorption is ?
questions.solution:
Urine total free deoxypyridinoline is a marker of bone resorption.

Markers of bone resorption:

  • Urine and serum cross linked N telopeptide
  • Urine and serum cross linked C telopeptide
  • Urine total free deoxypyridinoline
  • Urine hydroxyproline
  • Urine hydroxylysine glycosides
  • Serum Tatarate Resistant Acid Phosphatase (TRAP)
  • Serum bone sialoprotein

Markers of bone formation:

  • Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase
  • Serum Osteocalcin
  • Serum peptide of type I procollagen
  • Type I collagen extension peptide

questions.text: The bone tumor which can cause hyperglycemia is
questions.solution:
Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85 % of cases.

Chondrosarcoma

  • Second in frequency to osteosarcoma
  • No neoplastic osteoid
  • Long history, pain not a prominent feature
  • X ray – ‘Popcorn’ calcification , ‘punctate’ or ‘comma’ calcification
  • Treatment – Wide local excision / Radical excision

questions.text: A 5 year old boy fell on his outstretched hand. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following vessel is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus and injury to the brachial artery is the most common vascular complication.

The fracture most commonly caused by a fall on an outstretched hand in a child is the supracondylar fracture of the humerus. As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in a fracture of the humerus above the condyles.

  • The brachial artery is usually injured by the sharp edge of the proximal fragment.
  • Sometimes flexor muscles of the forearm - flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus (medial-half) may suffer ischemic damage leading to Volkmann's ischemia leading to compartment syndrome.

While injury to the brachial artery is the commonest vascular complication, however, malunion is the most common complication of supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Other delayed complications:

  • Malunion - Cubitus varus / Gunstock deformity
  • Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture
  • Myositis ossificans

 

Related Pearl: Orthopedic trauma and associated vascular injuries

Injuries Vessel involved
Dislocations:
Shoulder dislocation Axillary
Posterior dislocation of the elbow Brachial
Hip dislocation Femoral
Knee dislocation Popliteal
Fractures:
Fracture proximal humerus Axillary
Supracondylar fracture humerus Brachial
Fracture both bones forearm Anterior interosseous artery
First rib fracture Subclavian
Pelvic fracture Presacral and internal iliac
Fracture femur Femoral
Supracondylar fracture femur Popliteal
Proximal tibial fracture Popliteal or its branches
Ankle injuries Posterior tibial

questions.text: The resorption surface can be distinguished from the bone formation surface by identifying the _________.
questions.solution:
Howship lacunae help in distinguishing the resorption surface from bone formation surface.

Osteoclast-mediated resorption of bone takes place in scalloped areas which are referred to as Howship lacunae (resorptive pits).

Haversian canals are central canals surrounded by a series of concentric lamellae. These run longitudinally.

Volkmann’s canals run from the endosteal to the periosteal surface, horizontally.

Sharpey fibers are strands of fibrous tissue connecting the bone to the periosteum.

Arrows in the electron micrograph depicted below points Howship lacunae. An osteoclast (Oc) showing ruffled border (RB) and clear zone (CZ) is in close juxtaposition to the resorptive pits.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the major diagnostic triad of fat embolism syndrome (FES)?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in urine is a minor criterion in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is caused by the release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the bloodstream. It usually occurs following long bone or pelvic fractures, and multiple fractures.

Along with platelet aggregates, the globules result in the following manifestations which make up the major diagnostic triad:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
  • Neurological impairment
  • Petechial rash

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A subperiosteally placed graft is called:
questions.solution:
A phemister bone graft is placed subperiosteally and is most commonly used in the tibial injuries.

Other options:

  • A cancellous bone graft is useful in defects less than 2.5 cm. it is rapidly revascularised.
  • A cortical bone graft provides fixation and osteogenesis. It can be used for the non union of shafts of long bones.

questions.text: Pseudoarthrosis may be seen in all of the following conditions except _______
questions.solution:
Pseudoarthosis is not seen in Osteomyelitis.

Pseudoarthrosis refers to the formation of a false joint that may develop after a fracture that has not united properly due to inadequate immobilization.

The central portion of the callus undergoes cystic degeneration and the luminal surface can become lined by synovial like cells, creating a false joint filled with clear fluids.

Causes of pseudoarthrosis include neurofibromatosis, non union, idiopathic, osteogenesis imperfecta, ankylosing spondylitis, fibrous dysplasia, and congenital causes.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He has swelling and pain on his left elbow. X-ray done is given below. Which of the following vessels is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray is suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus in which brachial artery is most commonly injured.

When there is vascular injury, the patient may complain of paraesthesia or numbness distal to the injury. On examination, the injured limb will be pale or slightly cyanosed, cold, and the pulse will be weak or absent. 

If a vascular injury is suspected, an angiogram or duplex scan is done immediately. If the test detects vascular injury, emergency treatment must be initiated without much delay.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic trauma and associated vascular injuries

Injuries Vessel involved
Dislocations:
Shoulder dislocation Axillary
Posterior dislocation of the elbow Brachial
Hip dislocation Femoral
Knee dislocation Popliteal
Fractures:
Fracture proximal humerus Axillary
Supracondylar fracture humerus Brachial
Fracture both bones forearm Anterior interosseous artery
First rib fracture Subclavian
Pelvic fracture Presacral and internal iliac
Fracture femur Femoral
Supracondylar fracture femur Popliteal
Proximal tibial fracture Popliteal or its branches
Ankle injuries Posterior tibial

questions.text: The equipment shown in the picture below is used to treat ____________
questions.solution:
The image shows Thomas splint which is used in the treatment of fracture shaft of the femur.

It is also used as a first-aid measure.

It is used for the transportation of injured patients and in joint diseases like tuberculosis of the knee.

Identification:

  • It has a padded metal oval ring set at an angle of 120 degree to inner bar
  • It has two sidebars, the outer bar is longer than inner bar
  • Distal end is w shaped.

questions.text: Triple deformity occurs in:
questions.solution:
The Triple deformity is seen in

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Hemophilia
  • Tuberculosis
  • Polio
  • Triple deformity of knee is the one in which flexion, external rotation, valgus at knee associated with posterior subluxation of tibia occurs.

questions.text: Kyphosis is maximum in which of the following regions?
questions.solution: Tuberculosis is the most common cause for kyphosis in India. Kyphosis is maximum in the thoracic spine because of normal kyphotic curvature. In the lumbar region, it is slight because of normal lordosis, in which most of the body weight is transmitted posteriorly and collapse is partial. And in the cervical spine, collapse is minimal, as most of the bony weight is borne through the articular process.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding reactive arthritis?

choices.text: It is most common among young men.
It is linked with the HLA-B27 locus.
X-ray evidence of sacro-ilitis is found in patients with long standing disease.
Poststreptococcal reactive arthritis responds well to aspirin

questions.solution:
Poststreptococcal reactive arthritis responds poorly to aspirin.

Reactive arthritis is most common among young men and has been linked to HLA-B27. It is a painful asymmetric oligo-arthritis that mainly affects the knees, ankles, and feet. Low back pain is common and evidence of sacroilitis in chronic disease is a usual finding. Most cases recover within 6 months but the prolonged recurrent disease may occur in chlamydial infections. Reactive arthritis is not migratory. Frequent causes are Chlamydia, Yersinia, Shigella, Campylobacter, and Salmonella.
